newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico bellwether Cetes rate up on inflation fears.
newsitem.headline: Mexico bellwether Cetes rate up on inflation fears.

text.p: Mexico's bellwether one-month primary Cetes rate rose at the auction on Tuesday on expectations of higher inflation, analysts said.
But a decline in longer-term rates showed that the trend for inflation was down, they said.
The one-month paper rate rose 180 basis points to 27.70 percent at the auction. The 91-day Cetes were assigned at 28.79 percent, four basis points higher than last week.
The rate on the 182-day paper fell 24 basis points to 28.81 percent. One-year paper was at 28.41 percent, compared with 28.65 percent last week.

Inverlat analyst Francisco Gutierrez said the rise in the 28-day paper reflected "the pressure that inflation is putting on rates, while the decline in the longer terms reflects a clear downward trend (in inflation)".
He said Cetes rates had risen recently due to an over-reaction in the secondary money market to exchange rate volatility and to short-term political and economic uncertainty.
Analysts said the results of the auction were as expected and that treasury bill rates could stabilise at around present levels.
"The auction went as expected, with mixed results. We are expecting that with this increase, rates will stabilise at these levels," said one market analyst.
"However, everything depends on the reaction of the exchange rate. But I don't think that any increases in rates ... will be very large," the analyst said.
The Cetes yield curve has been flattening in recent auctions.
Banco de Mexico recently tightened its liquidity objective in the money markets while the peso has been weakening.
However, inflationary pressures are expected to ease over time and that has allowed long-term rates to fall.
